text: God, who at sundry times and in divers manners spoke in times past unto the fathers by the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: hath in these last days spoken unto us by His Son, whom He hath appointed Heir of all things, by whom also He made the worlds,
speaker: Narrator

text: who being the brightness of His glory and the express image of His person, upholding all things by the word of His power, when He had by Himself purged our sins, sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high,
speaker: Narrator

text: being made so much better than the angels, as He hath by inheritance obtained a more excellent name than they.
speaker: Narrator

text: For unto which of the angels said God at any time, “Thou art My Son; this day have I begotten Thee”? And again, “I will be to Him a Father, and He shall be to Me a Son”?
speaker: Narrator

text: And again, when He bringeth in the First-Begotten into the world, He saith, “And let all the angels of God worship Him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And of the angels He saith, “Who maketh His angels spirits and His ministers a flame of fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But unto the Son He saith, “Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever; a scepter of righteousness is the scepter of Thy Kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast loved righteousness and hated iniquity; therefore God, even Thy God, hath anointed Thee with the oil of gladness above Thy fellows.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And, “Thou, Lord, in the beginning hast laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the works of Thine hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall perish, but Thou remainest; and they all shall wax old as doth a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as a vesture shalt Thou fold them up, and they shall be changed. But Thou art the same, and Thy years shall not fail.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But to which of the angels said He at any time, “Sit on My right hand until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool”?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are they not all ministering spirits, sent forth to minister for those who shall be heirs of salvation?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore we ought to give even more earnest heed to the things which we have heard, lest at any time we should let them slip.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the word spoken by angels was steadfast, and every transgression and disobedience received a just recompense of reward,
speaker: Narrator

text: how shall we escape if we neglect so great a salvation, which at the first began to be spoken by the Lord and was confirmed unto us by those who heard Him,
speaker: Narrator

text: God also bearing them witness, both with signs and wonders and with divers miracles and gifts of the Holy Ghost, according to His own will?
speaker: Narrator

text: For it was not unto angels that He put in subjection the world to come, of which we speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one at a certain place testified, saying, “What is man, that Thou art mindful of him? Or the son of man, that Thou visitest him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou madest him a little lower than the angels; Thou crowned him with glory and honor and set him over the works of Thy hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast put all things in subjection under his feet.” For in putting all in subjection under him, He left nothing that is not put under him. But now as yet we see not all things put under him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we see Jesus, who was made a little lower than the angels for the suffering of death, crowned with glory and honor, that He by the grace of God should taste death for every man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it became Him, for whom are all things, and by whom are all things, in bringing many sons unto glory, to make the Captain of their salvation perfect through sufferings.
speaker: Narrator

text: For both He that sanctifieth and they who are sanctified are all of One, for which cause He is not ashamed to call them brethren,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “I will declare Thy name unto My brethren; in the midst of the church will I sing praise unto Thee.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And again, “I will put My trust in Him.” And again, “Behold I and the children whom God hath given Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, He also Himself likewise took part of the same, that through death He might destroy him that had the power of death — that is, the devil —
speaker: Narrator

text: and deliver those who all their lifetime were subject to bondage through fear of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: For verily He took not on Himself the nature of angels, but He took on Him the seed of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore in all things it behooved Him to be made like unto His brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful High Priest in things pertaining to God, to make reconciliation for the sins of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in that He Himself hath suffered, being tempted, He is able to succor those who are tempted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, holy brethren, partakers of the heavenly calling, consider the Apostle and High Priest of our profession, Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was faithful to Him that appointed Him, as also Moses was faithful in all His house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this Man was counted worthy of more glory than Moses, inasmuch as He who hath built the house hath more honor than the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every house is built by some man, but He that built all things is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses verily was faithful in all His house as a servant, as a testimony of those things which were to be spoken thereafter;
speaker: Narrator

text: but Christ was faithful as a Son over His own house, whose house are we if we hold fast the confidence and rejoicing of the hope, firm unto the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore as the Holy Ghost saith: “Today if ye will hear His voice,
speaker: Narrator

text: harden not your hearts as in the provocation, in the day of temptation in the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text: when your fathers tempted Me, proved Me, and saw My works forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I was grieved with that generation, and said, ‘They do always err in their heart, and they have not known My ways.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I swore in My wrath, ‘They shall not enter into My rest.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Take heed, brethren, lest there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief, in departing from the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But exhort one another daily, while it is still called “today,” lest any of you be hardened through the deceitfulness of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are made partakers of Christ if we hold the confidence we had in the beginning steadfast unto the end,
speaker: Narrator

text: while it is said, “Today if ye will hear His voice, harden not your hearts as in the provocation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For some, when they had heard, did provoke, however not all that came out of Egypt by Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But with whom was He grieved forty years? Was it not with those who had sinned, whose carcasses fell in the wilderness?
speaker: Narrator

text: And to whom did He swear that they should not enter into His rest, but to those who believed not?
speaker: Narrator

text: So we see that they could not enter in because of unbelief.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us therefore fear, lest, a promise being left to us of entering into His rest, any of you should seem to come short of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For unto us was the Gospel preached, as well as unto them; but the Word preached did not profit them, not being mixed with faith in those who heard it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we who have believed do enter into rest, as He said, “As I have sworn in My wrath, ‘If they shall enter into My rest’”—although the works were finished from the foundation of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He spoke in a certain place of the seventh day in this way: “And God rested on the seventh day from all His works.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And again in this place: “If they shall enter into My rest”—.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seeing therefore it remaineth that some must enter therein, and those to whom it was first preached did not enter in because of unbelief,
speaker: Narrator

text: again He designates a certain day, saying in David “today,” after so long a time, as it is said, “Today if you will hear His voice, harden not your hearts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For if Joshua had given them rest, then He would not afterwards have spoken of another day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There remaineth therefore a rest for the people of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he that has entered into His rest, he also hath ceased from his own works, as God did from His.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us labor therefore to enter into that rest, lest any man fall according to the same example of unbelief.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Word of God is living and powerful and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither is there any creature that is not manifest in His sight, but all things are naked and open unto the eyes of Him with whom we have to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seeing then that we have a great High Priest who has passed into the Heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast to our profession.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we do not have a High Priest who cannot be touched with the feelings of our infirmities, but was in all points tempted as we are, yet without sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us therefore come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy and find grace to help in time of need.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every high priest taken from among men is ordained for men in things pertaining to God, that he may offer both gifts and sacrifices for sins;
speaker: Narrator

text: who can have compassion on the ignorant and on those who are outside of the Way, since he himself is also encompassed by infirmity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And by reason hereof, he ought, both for the people and also for himself, to make offering for sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: And no man taketh this honor unto himself, except he that is called by God, as was Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: So also Christ glorified not Himself to be made a high priest, but He that said unto Him, “Thou art My Son; today have I begotten Thee.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And He saith also in another place, “Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Christ, in the days of His flesh, when He had offered up prayers and supplications with strong crying and tears unto Him that was able to save Him from death, and was heard in that He feared,
speaker: Narrator

text: though He were a Son, yet learned He obedience by the things which He suffered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And being made perfect, He became the author of eternal salvation unto all those who obey Him,
speaker: Narrator

text: being called by God as a high priest after the order of Melchizedek,
speaker: Narrator

text: of whom we have many things to say, which are hard to utter seeing ye are dull of hearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: For at the time when ye ought to be teachers, ye have need that one teach you again the first principles of the oracles of God, and have become such as have need of milk, and not of strong meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every one that useth milk is unskilled in the word of righteousness, for he is a babe.
speaker: Narrator

text: But strong meat belongeth to those who are of full age, even those who by reason of use have their senses exercised to discern both good and evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, leaving the principles of the doctrine of Christ, let us go on unto perfection, not laying again the foundation of repentance from dead works and of faith toward God,
speaker: Narrator

text: of the doctrine of baptisms and of laying on of hands, and of resurrection of the dead and of eternal judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this we will do, if God permit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is impossible for those who were once enlightened and have tasted of the heavenly gift, and were made partakers of the Holy Ghost,
speaker: Narrator

text: and have tasted the good Word of God and the powers of the world to come,
speaker: Narrator

text: if they shall fall away, to renew them again unto repentance, seeing that they crucify to themselves the Son of God afresh and put Him to open shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the earth which drinketh in the rain that cometh oft upon it, and bringeth forth herbs meet for those by whom it is dressed, receiveth blessing from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But that which beareth thorns and briars is rejected and is nigh unto being cursed, whose end is to be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, beloved, though we thus speak, we are persuaded that there are better things for you, things that accompany salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God is not unrighteous so as to forget your work and labor of love, which ye have shown toward His name, in that ye have ministeredto the saints, and do minister.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we desire that every one of you show the same diligence to the full assurance of hope unto the end,
speaker: Narrator

text: that ye be not slothful, but followers of those who through faith and patience inherit the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when God made promise to Abraham, because He could swear by no greater, He swore by Himself,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “Surely in blessing I will bless thee, and in multiplying I will multiply thee.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so, after he had patiently endured, he obtained the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For men verily swear by the greater, and an oath of confirmation is to them an end to all strife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thereby God, willing more abundantly to show unto the heirs of promise the immutability of His counsel, confirmed it by an oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: that by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we, who have fled for refuge, might have strong consolation to lay hold upon the hope set before us.
speaker: Narrator

text: This hope we have as an anchor of the soul, both sure and steadfast, and which entereth into that within the veil,
speaker: Narrator

text: where the Forerunner has entered for us, even Jesus, who is made a high priest forever, after the order of Melchizedek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, met Abraham, who was returning from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: To him also Abraham gave a tenth part of all, Melchizedek first being by interpretation “king of righteousness,” and after that also king of Salem, which means “king of peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Without father, without mother and without descent, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but made like unto the Son of God, he abideth a priest continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now consider how great this man was, unto whom even the patriarch Abraham gave a tenth of the spoils.
speaker: Narrator

text: And verily, those who are of the sons of Levi, who receive the office of the priesthood, have a commandment to take tithes from the people according to the law — that is, from their brethren — though they come out of the loins of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Melchizedek, whose descent is not counted from them, received tithes from Abraham and blessed him that had the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: And beyond all contradiction, the lesser is blessed by the greater.
speaker: Narrator

text: And here men who die receive tithes; but there he receiveth them, of whom it is witnessed that he liveth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And, as I may so say, Levi also, who receiveth tithes, paid tithes through Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he was yet in the loins of his father when Melchizedek met Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: If therefore perfection were through the Levitical priesthood (for under it the people received the law), what further need was there that another priest should rise according to the order of Melchizedek, and not be called according to the order of Aaron?
speaker: Narrator

text: For the priesthood being changed, there is made of necessity a change also of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He of whom these things are spoken pertaineth to another tribe, of which no man gave attendance at the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is evident that our Lord sprang out of Judah, of which tribe Moses spoke nothing concerning priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is yet far more evident when there ariseth another priest according to the similitude of Melchizedek,
speaker: Narrator

text: who is made not according to the law of a carnal commandment, but according to the power of an endless life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He testifieth: “Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is verily an annulling of the former commandment because of the weakness and unprofitableness thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law made nothing perfect, but the bringing in of a better hope did, by which we draw nigh unto God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And inasmuch as it was not without an oath that He was made priest
speaker: Narrator

text: (for those priests were made without an oath, but He with an oath by Him who said unto Him: “The Lord swore and will not repent, ‘Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek.’”),
speaker: Narrator

text: by so much more was Jesus made a surety of a better testament.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those priests truly were many, because they were not suffered to continue by reason of death;
speaker: Narrator

text: but this Man, because He continueth forever, hath an unchangeable priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore He is able also to save to the uttermost those who come unto God by Him, seeing He ever liveth to make intercession for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For such a High Priest who is befitting for us, holy, undisposed to harm, undefiled, separated from sinners, and made higher than the heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text: who needeth not, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifice daily first for His own sins and then for the people’s; for this He did once when He offered up Himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law maketh men high priests who have infirmity; but the word of the oath, which came since the law, maketh the Son, who is consecrated for evermore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now of the things of which we have spoken, this is the sum: We have such a High Priest, who is set on the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text: a minister of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle, which the Lord pitched and not man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every high priest is ordained to offer gifts and sacrifices; therefore it is of necessity that this Man have something also to offer.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if He were on earth, He should not be a priest, seeing that there are priests who offer gifts according to the law,
speaker: Narrator

text: and who serve unto the copy and shadow of heavenly things, as Moses was admonished by God when he was about to make the tabernacle. For, “See,” saith He, “that thou make all things according to the pattern shown to thee on the mount.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now hath He obtained a more excellent ministry, by how much also He is the Mediator of a better covenant, which was established upon better promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if that first covenant had been faultless, then should no place have been sought for the second.
speaker: Narrator

text: For finding fault with them, He saith, “Behold, the days come,” saith the Lord, “when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah—
speaker: Narrator

text: not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers in the day when I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt, because they continued not in My covenant, and I regarded them not, saith the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, saith the Lord: I will put My laws into their minds and write them in their hearts, and I will be to them a God, and they shall be to Me a people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall not teach every man his neighbor and every man his brother, saying, ‘Know the Lord,’ for all shall know Me, from the least to the greatest.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will be merciful to their unrighteousness, and their sins and their iniquities will I remember no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that He saith “a new covenant,” He hath made the first old. Now that which decayeth and waxeth old is ready to vanish away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then verily, the first covenant also had ordinances of divine service and a worldly sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there was a tabernacle made, the first, wherein was the candlestick and the table and the showbread, which is called the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after the second veil was the tabernacle which is called the Holiest of All,
speaker: Narrator

text: which had the golden censer, and the ark of the covenant overlaid round about with gold, wherein was the golden pot that had manna, and Aaron’s rod that budded, and the tablets of the covenant;
speaker: Narrator

text: and over it were the cherubims of glory shadowing the mercy seat, of which we cannot now speak particularly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when these things were thus ordained, the priests went always into the first tabernacle, accomplishing the service to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But into the second went the high priest alone once every year, not without blood, which he offered for himself and for the errors of the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Holy Ghost by this signifying that the way into the Holiest of All was not yet made manifest so long as the first tabernacle was yet standing.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was a figure for the time then present in which were offered both gifts and sacrifices, which could not make him that did the service perfect, as pertaining to the conscience,
speaker: Narrator

text: since it concerned only meats and drinks and divers washings and carnal ordinances imposed on them until the time of reformation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Christ, having come a High Priest of good things to come, by a greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands (that is to say, not of this building),
speaker: Narrator

text: neither by the blood of goats and calves, but by His own blood, He entered in once into the Holy Place, having obtained eternal redemption for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if sprinkling the unclean with the blood of bulls and goats and the ashes of a heifer sanctifieth to the purifying of the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: how much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered Himself without spot to God, purge your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?
speaker: Narrator

text: And for this cause He is the Mediator of the new testament, that by means of death, for the redemption of the transgressions that were covered under the first testament, those who are called might receive the promise of eternal inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where a testament is, there must also of necessity be the death of the testator.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a testament is of force after men are dead, otherwise it is of no strength at all while the testator liveth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so not even the first testament was dedicated without blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when Moses had spoken every precept to all the people according to the law, he took the blood of calves and of goats, with water and scarlet wool and hyssop, and sprinkled both the book and all the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “This is the blood of the testament which God hath enjoined unto you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover he sprinkled with blood both the tabernacle and all the vessels of the ministry.
speaker: Narrator

text: And by the law almost all things are purged with blood, and without shedding of blood there is no remission.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was therefore necessary that the copies of things in the heavens should be purified with these, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ has not entered into the holy places made with hands, which are copies of the true, but into Heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor yet should He offer Himself often, as the high priest entereth into the holy place with blood of others every year;
speaker: Narrator

text: for then would He have had to suffer often since the foundation of the world; but now once, in the end of the world, hath He appeared to put away sin by the sacrifice of Himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as it is appointed unto men once to die, but after this the Judgment,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Christ was once offered to bear the sins of many; and unto those who look for Him shall He appear the second time without sin, unto salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law, having a shadow of the good things to come and not the very image of those things, can never, with those sacrifices which they offered continually year by year, make those who come unto it perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: For then would not sacrifices have ceased to be offered? For worshipers once purged should have had no more consciousness of sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in those sacrifices there is a remembrance again made of sins every year,
speaker: Narrator

text: for it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of goats should take away sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore when He cometh into the world, He saith, “Sacrifice and offering Thou wouldest not have, but a body hast Thou prepared for Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: In burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin Thou hast had no pleasure.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said I, ‘Lo, I come (in the volume of the Book it is written of Me) to do Thy will, O God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Above when He said, “Sacrifice and offering and burnt offerings, and offering for sin Thou wouldest not have, neither hadst pleasure therein” (which are offered in accordance with the law),
speaker: Narrator

text: then said He, “Lo, I come to do Thy will, O God,” He taketh away the first, that He may establish the second.
speaker: Narrator

text: By this will we are sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
speaker: Narrator

text: And every priest standeth daily ministering and offering time and again the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this Man, after He had offered one sacrifice for sins for ever, sat down at the right hand of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: from henceforth to wait until His enemies be made His footstool.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by one offering He hath perfected for ever those who are sanctified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of this the Holy Ghost also is a witness to us; for after He had said before,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the covenant that I will make with them after those days, saith the Lord: I will put My laws into their hearts, and in their minds will I write them;
speaker: Narrator

text: and their sins and iniquities will I remember no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now where remission of these is, there is no more offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Having therefore boldness, brethren, to enter into the Holiest by the blood of Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: by a new and living Way, which He hath consecrated for us through the veil (that is to say, His flesh),
speaker: Narrator

text: and having a High Priest over the house of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience and our bodies washed with pure water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us hold fast to the profession of our faith without wavering (for He is faithful who promised),
speaker: Narrator

text: and let us consider one another to provoke unto love and to good works,
speaker: Narrator

text: not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together, as is the manner of some, but exhorting one another, and so much the more as ye see the Day approaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we sin willfully after having received the knowledge of the truth, there remaineth no more sacrifice for sins,
speaker: Narrator

text: but a certain fearful expectation of judgment and fiery indignation, which shall devour the adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that despised Moses’ law died without mercy on the testimony of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of how much sorer punishment, suppose ye, shall he be thought worthy who hath trodden under foot the Son of God, and hath accounted the blood of the covenant, wherewith he was sanctified, an unholy thing, and hath despised the Spirit of grace?
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know Him that hath said, “Vengeance belongeth unto Me; I will recompense,” saith the Lord. And again, “The Lord shall judge His people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But call to remembrance the former days in which, after ye were illuminated, ye endured a great fight of afflictions,
speaker: Narrator

text: partly while ye were being made a gazingstock both by reproaches and afflictions, and partly while ye became companions of those who were so used.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye had compassion on me in my bonds and took joyfully the despoiling of your goods, knowing in yourselves that ye have in Heaven a better and an enduring substance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cast not away therefore your confidence, which hath great recompense of reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye have need of patience, that, after ye have done the will of God, ye might receive the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For yet a little while, and He that shall come will come, and will not tarry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the just shall live by faith; but if any man draw back, My soul shall have no pleasure in him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But we are not of those who draw back unto perdition, but of those who believe, to the saving of the soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by it the elders obtained a good report.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through faith we understand that the worlds were framed by the Word of God, so that things which are seen were not made of things which do appear.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abel offered unto God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain, by which he obtained witness that he was righteous, God testifying of his gifts; and by it he, being dead, yet speaketh.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Enoch was translated, that he should not see death, “and was not found because God had translated him.” For before his translation he had this testimony: that he pleased God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But without faith it is impossible to please Him. For he that cometh to God must believe that He is, and that He is a rewarder of those who diligently seek Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Noah, being warned by God of things not yet seen, moved with fear, prepared an ark for the saving of his house, by which he condemned the world and became heir of the righteousness which is by faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abraham, when he was called to go out into a place which he should later receive for an inheritance, obeyed; and he went out, not knowing whither he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he sojourned in the land of promise as in a strange country, dwelling in tabernacles with Isaac and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through faith also Sarah herself received strength to conceive seed, and was delivered of a child when she was past the age, because she judged Him faithful who had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore there sprang even from one, and him as good as dead, as many as the stars of the sky in multitude, and innumerable as the sand which is by the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: These all died in faith, not having received the promises but having seen them afar off, and were persuaded by them and embraced them, and confessed that they were strangers and pilgrims on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who say such things declare plainly that they are seeking a fatherland.
speaker: Narrator

text: And truly, if they had been mindful of that country from whence they came out, they might have had opportunity to have returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now they desire a better country, that is, a heavenly one. Therefore God is not ashamed to be called their God, for He hath prepared for them a City.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abraham, when he was tried, offered up Isaac; and he that had received the promises offered up his only begotten son,
speaker: Narrator

text: of whom it was said, “In Isaac shall thy seed be called,”
speaker: Narrator

text: accounting that God was able to raise him up even from the dead, from whence he also received him, in a figurative sense.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Jacob, when he was dying, blessed both the sons of Joseph and worshiped, leaning upon the top of his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Joseph, when he was dying, made mention of the departing of the children of Israel, and gave commandment concerning his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses, when he was born, was hidden three months by his parents, because they saw he was a handsome child; and they were not afraid of the king’s edict.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses, when he had come of age, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter,
speaker: Narrator

text: choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season,
speaker: Narrator

text: esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt; for he had respect unto the recompense of the reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he forsook Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king; for he endured as seeing Him who is invisible.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through faith he kept the Passover and the sprinkling of blood, lest he that destroyed the firstborn should touch them.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith they passed through the Red Sea as by dry land, but the Egyptians, in attempting to do so, were drowned.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the walls of Jericho fell down, after they had been compassed about for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the harlot Rahab perished not with those who believed not, having received the spies with peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what shall I say more? For the time would fail me to tell of Gideon and of Barak and of Samson and of Jephthah, of David also and Samuel and of the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: who through faith subdued kingdoms, wrought righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,
speaker: Narrator

text: quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword. Out of weakness they were made strong, waxed valiant in battle, and turned to flight the armies of the aliens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Women received their dead raised to life again, and others were tortured, not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection.
speaker: Narrator

text: And others endured the trial of cruel mockings and scourgings, yea moreover, of bonds and imprisonment.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were stoned, they were sawn asunder, were tempted, were slain with the sword. They wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented
speaker: Narrator

text: (of whom the world was not worthy). They wandered in deserts and in mountains, and in dens and caves of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And these all, having obtained a good report through faith, received not the promise,
speaker: Narrator

text: God having provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, seeing we also are compassed about by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us,
speaker: Narrator

text: looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith, who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For consider Him that endured such contradiction from sinners against Himself, lest ye be wearied and faint in your minds.
speaker: Narrator

text: In striving against sin, ye have not yet resisted unto bloodshed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And ye have forgotten the exhortation which speaketh unto you as unto children: “My son, despise not thou the chastening of the Lord, nor faint when thou art rebuked by Him;
speaker: Narrator

text: for whom the Lord loveth He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If ye endure chastening, God dealeth with you as with sons; for what son is he whom the father chasteneth not?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if ye be without chastisement, whereof all arepartakers, then ye are bastards and not sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore we have had fathers of our flesh who corrected us, and we gave them reverence. Shall we not far rather be in subjection unto the Father of Spirits, and live?
speaker: Narrator

text: For verily they chastened us for a few days according to their own pleasure, but He for our profit, that we might be partakers of His holiness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now no chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous; nevertheless afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness unto those who are exercised thereby.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, lift up the hands which hang down and the feeble knees,
speaker: Narrator

text: and make straight paths for your feet, lest that which is lame be turned out of the way, but let it rather be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Follow peace with all men, and holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: looking diligently lest any man fail of the grace of God; lest any root of bitterness spring up to trouble you, and thereby many be defiled;
speaker: Narrator

text: lest there be any fornicator or profane person as Esau, who for one morsel of meat sold his birthright.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye know how afterward, when he would have inherited the blessing, he was rejected; for he found no place of repentance, though he sought it diligently with tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye have not come unto the mount which might be touched and that burned with fire, nor unto blackness and darkness and tempest,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sound of a trumpet and the voice of words, which voice those who heard entreated that the Word should not be spoken to them any more.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For they could not endure that which was commanded, that: “if even so much as a beast touch the mountain, it shall be stoned or thrust through with a dart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so terrible was the sight that Moses said, “I fear exceedingly and quake.”)
speaker: Narrator

text: But ye have come unto Mount Zion and unto the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to an innumerable company of angels,
speaker: Narrator

text: to the general assembly and church of the firstborn, who are written in Heaven, and to God the Judge of all, and to the spirits of just men made perfect,
speaker: Narrator

text: and to Jesus the Mediator of the new covenant, and to the blood of sprinkling, that speaketh better things than that of Abel.
speaker: Narrator

text: See that ye refuse not Him that speaketh, for if they escaped not who refused Him that spoke on earth, much more shall we not escape if we turn away from Him that speaketh from Heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: whose voice then shook the earth. But now He hath promised, saying, “Yet once more I shake not the earth only, but also heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And these words, “yet once more,” signifieth the removing of those things which can be shaken, such as things that are made, that those things which cannot be shaken may remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, we receiving a Kingdom which cannot be moved, let us have grace whereby we may serve God acceptably, with reverence and godly fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: For our God is a consuming fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let brotherly love continue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be not forgetful to entertain strangers, for thereby some have entertained angels unawares.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember those who are in bonds as though you were bound with them, and thse who suffer adversity, as being yourselves also in the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Marriage is honorable in all, and the bed undefiled; but whoremongers and adulterers God will judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your manner of living be without covetousness, and be content with such things as ye have. For He hath said, “I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee”;
speaker: Narrator

text: so that we may boldly say, “The Lord is my helper, and I will not fear what man shall do unto me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember those who have the rule over you, who have spoken unto you the Word of God. Follow their faith, considering the outcome of their manner of living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, and today, and for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be not carried about with divers and strange doctrines. For it is a good thing that the heart be established with grace, not with meats which have not profited those who have been occupied therewith.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have an altar from which they have no right to eat, who serve the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the bodies of those beasts, whose blood is brought into the sanctuary by the high priest for sin, are burned outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Jesus also, that He might sanctify the people with His own blood, suffered outside the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us go forth therefore unto Him outside the camp, bearing His reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: For here we have no continuing city, but we seek one to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: By Him therefore let us offer the sacrifice of praise to God continually, that is, the fruit of our lips giving thanks to His name.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to do good and to communicate forget not, for with such sacrifices God is well pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey those who have the rule over you and submit yourselves, for they keep watch over your souls as ones who must give an account, that they may do it with joy and not with grief, for that is unprofitable for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray for us, for we trust we have a good conscience in all things, willing to live honestly.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I beseech you the more earnestly to do this, that I may be restored to you the sooner.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the God of peace, who brought back from the dead our Lord Jesus, that great Shepherd of the sheep, through the blood of the everlasting covenant,
speaker: Narrator

text: make you perfect in every good work to do His will, working in you that which is well pleasing in His sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory for ever and ever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I beseech you, brethren, suffer the word of exhortation, for I have written this letter unto you with few words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know ye that our brother Timothy is set at liberty, with whom, if he come shortly, I will see you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Salute all those who have the rule over you, and all the saints. Those from Italy salute you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grace be with you all. Amen.
speaker: Narrator
